title: Ops Resilience: Never Again
description: Power is restored. The PM wants answers: who did this, how did they do it, and what stops it happening again? DIS has one week to brief Parliament.
storyContext: Power is back. Singapore woke up, went to work, and most people will never know how close it got. But the PM knows, and Parliament wants answers. Your team has one week to produce a brief that explains who did this, how they got in, and what stops it from ever happening again. The evidence you present will shape national cybersecurity policy for the next decade. Get it right.

software-engineer.title: Design the Permanent Defence
software-engineer.instruction: The attack exploited a gap between the power station control systems and the office IT network. Leadership wants a permanent technical solution. What do you propose?
software-engineer.hint: The best long-term defence closes the gap without creating new operational problems, including making it impossible to manage systems remotely.

options.label: Build a system where every connection between power stations and office networks must prove it is legitimate before being allowed through. Nothing is trusted by default, even from inside the building. The gold standard for security but takes 18 months to fully roll out.

Set up an AI-powered security centre that watches the power stations and office networks around the clock. It flags suspicious activity and automatically responds to known threats. Operational in 3 months.
Physically cut all internet connections to the critical power control systems forever. The ultimate defence but makes remote management impossible: every software update needs an engineer on-site.
Create a regional programme where neighbouring countries' power utilities share attack details in real time. One country detecting an attack means everyone else is warned immediately.

data-scientist.title: Build the Evidence Case
data-scientist.instruction: Intelligence suggests a state-backed attacker but the PM needs solid evidence before Parliament. Put these steps in the right order to build a credible case.
data-scientist.hint: Gather all the evidence before drawing conclusions. Build from the most concrete facts toward the broader picture, and always be honest about how certain you are.

items.label: Compare the attacker's methods and tools against a database of known criminal groups to find a match
Trace the network traffic backwards through disguised relay points to find where the attack was actually controlled from
Study the malicious code for stylistic clues, the same way you might analyse handwriting, to work out who wrote it
Check when the attacks happened against the working hours and time zones of suspected groups
Combine all the evidence into a clear statement for Parliament, with an honest note on how certain you are

cloud-engineer.title: Design the Resilience Architecture
cloud-engineer.instruction: Design an infrastructure that survives future attacks. Drag each component to the right layer of the defence. Layer 1 stops attacks before they start. Layers 2 and 3 detect and respond. Layer 4 recovers when things do go wrong.
cloud-engineer.hint: Think about each tool's purpose: stopping, spotting, reacting, or recovering. Assign each to the layer that matches its job.

items.label: Traffic Filter (blocks suspicious incoming traffic at the gate)
Threat Detection Console (monitors and flags suspicious events)
Auto-Response Engine (automatically acts on confirmed threats)
Backup Control Centre (takes over if the main site goes down)
Weakness Finder (regularly scans for security gaps before attackers do)
Protected Backup Vault (stores clean backups the attacker can't tamper with)
